Arrr, matey, let me tell ye 'bout Rocket League, the game that be so simple, yet so devilishly addictin’ that it could make even the saltiest pirate give up his treasure hunt just to kick around a giant ball with rocket-powered carriages!

Picture this: ye be sailin' the vast seas of outer space (because why not), drivin' a car that shoots into the air like a cannonball—aye, forget yer sails, ye got rockets strapped to yer hull! The goal? To play football... with said rocket-powered ships. Aye, ye heard right. No swords, no cannons, just ye, yer ship, and a giant ball that apparently has a mind of its own, bouncin' around like a crazed parrot on grog.

But here be the real magic, ye see—the controls. Arrr, they be smoother than a freshly polished deck. Just press this, steer that, and before ye know it, ye be flyin' through the air like a majestic sea bird, only to completely miss the ball by a country mile! But don’t worry, because the game gives ye a second chance, and a third, and a fourth... ye get the idea. Just keep swingin’ and prayin', ye might hit it eventually.

The crew, aye, the crew! Ye get paired with other sea dogs who seem to have forgotten how to steer. One moment they be helpin’ ye score the winning goal, and the next they be ramming ye into oblivion, sendin' ye flyin’ faster than a cannon blast. It’s all part of the fun, ye see—teamwork or utter chaos, ye never know which ye’ll get!

And the arenas! By Davy Jones’ beard, they be grander than any treasure hoard I’ve ever seen. Glorious stadiums where the crowd cheers louder than a fleet of pirate ships celebratin’ a victory! The thrill of chasin’ that ball, only to watch it fly over yer head as ye smash into the wall—‘tis a rush, matey, a rush like no other.

So if ye be lookin' for a game where ye can pretend ye have any control over a giant bouncin’ ball while ridin’ in a rocket-fueled carriage, Rocket League be the one for ye! Just don’t forget to bring yer sea legs—ye’ll be needin' 'em when ye inevitably crash and burn... again and again.

Arrr, 11 out of 10 cannonballs!

[h1]Gameplay experience[/h1]
My gameplay experience with Rocket League has been ok. I find the controls in this game difficult to use and the matchmaking does feel moderately balanced in some way. The game itself does keep me moderately interested and excited. 

The in-game choices during races does somewhat feel meaningful. Many stuffs happen at random and with luck it seems, but that is probably because my lack of skill with this game tbh I guess. Generally, I do not exactly fell satisfied with the rewards for progression and milestones in the game.


[h1]Presentation & Immersion[/h1]
RL’s presentation and immersion on the other hand is very good. The game is slightly interesting to play, but you play on a field that feels moderately immersive. The visual art style of the game though does feel extremely appealing. 

They also do deliver when it comes to their extremely engaging sounds and music. And the game provides a very user-friendly HUD and in-game menus.


[h1]Design & Technical Aspects[/h1]
The game is well designed regarding their game mechanics. The content in this game is extensive if we look at how well its crafted and how extensive it is in general. The AI operates average, and you’re able to customize the game settings at a flexible level. 

Through the game I haven’t experienced any technical issues or glitches. Only that it sometimes feels a bit laggy and getting a few lag spikes now and then.


[h1]Final Considerations[/h1]
Personally, I feel dissatisfied with Rocket League. It doesn’t give me that much joy playing it. Even if I loose or win, it doesn’t matter. Maybe its just not a game for me. 

The game has minimal micro-transactions and in-game purchases. Replay value of the game is moderate and I do believe the game at the end of the day is worth the value for it’s price. 

Even though the game does not fit me, I am still going to recommend it to others. 


[h1]Summary[/h1]

    [tr][td]Gameplay Experience:[/td]    [td]13 / 25[/td][/tr]
    [tr][td]Presentation & Immersion:[/td]    [td]20 / 25[/td][/tr]

In 2024, I do not recommend this game. 

Despite being one of the most unique games in the market in terms of game mechanics, you'll have both frustrating and rewarding times while playing it. If you have plenty of time to spare and no other games to play, then yeah, I do recommend Rocket League because there are simply no other like it in the market, and because your improvements are based on your skills alone and how much time spent on this.

However, I reached a plateau, my mechanics were degrading after the years, and I stopped having fun. I've been playing this game casually for a long time, and after 7 years, I decided to uninstall and un-list it for good, This review is my formal goodbye to this game that I sunk 13 hundred hours into. At the end, I had about 50/50 hours between fun and frustration while playing this game. Also, the community is one of the most toxic ones out there.

Rocket league genuine Gold 1 coaching tips;

Search for the training pack "Shooting Consistency" and follow these rules. give up after ten minutes.

Only go to the next part once you scored the shot 3 times.

If you miss 3 times, go back to the last part you did, then think of a way to blame it on your teammates.

Keep doing this until you finish half the training pack or if you're dedicated, begin to bind "what a save!" t all quick response slots.

This will help your ground shooting and even aerial shooting skills, and you'll get frustrated due to lack of improvement.

It trains your brain to not miss, because you know if you have to look in the mirror again knowing you spent 200 hours of your life to be stuck in plat 2 you're going to do something stupid with a handgun

Ah, Rocket League. The game where cars fly, balls soar, and dreams of reaching Grand Champion are crushed under the weight of reality. After nearly 3000 hours of game-play, I find myself still firmly planted in the Champion 1 rank, like a stubborn weed that refuses to grow any taller.

Game-play: Imagine a ballet, but instead of graceful dancers, you have rocket-powered cars. And instead of elegant moves, you have me and my friend flailing around the pitch like two headless chickens. We’ve mastered the art of the “almost aerial” and the “whiffed save.” Our teamwork is impeccable—if you count double-committing and bumping each other as teamwork.

Mechanics: In all this time, you’d think I’d have learned some proper mechanics. But no, my dribbling skills are more akin to a toddler with a beach ball. My flicks? More like gentle nudges. And let’s not even talk about my air dribbles—they’re more like air fumbles. My friend and I have perfected the “panic flip” and the “accidental own goal,” making us legends in our own right.

Progress: Despite playing nearly every day, our progress is like a snail on a treadmill—lots of effort, but we’re not getting anywhere. We’ve become the gatekeepers of Champion 1, ensuring no one else gets stuck here as long as we’re around. Our rank is as consistent as our ability to miss open nets.

Conclusion: Rocket League has given us countless hours of laughter, frustration, and the occasional moment of brilliance. While we may never escape the clutches of Champion 1, we’ve accepted our fate with a smile (and a lot of sarcastic comments). Here’s to another 3000 hours of glorious mediocrity!

Final Verdict: If you’re looking for a game that will test your patience, your friendships, and your ability to laugh at yourself, Rocket League is the perfect choice.

Rocket League was once the crown jewel of competitive gaming for me, a title that I absolutely adored. As a semi-pro collegiate player, I invested countless hours (over 5,000 hours across 3 different platforms and 6 different accounts to be specific) mastering every mechanic, every flick, and every aerial. It was a game that struck the perfect balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for those willing to put in the time. The rush of nailing a perfectly timed aerial goal or making a last-second save was unmatched.

However, it’s with a heavy heart that I say Rocket League has lost its magic. The game I once loved has been overshadowed by a series of changes and decisions from the developers that have shifted the focus away from what made it special. It feels as though the developers have sold out, prioritizing flashy cosmetics and monetization over the core gameplay experience. Instead of rewarding dedication and skill, it seems like everything has been tailored toward quick profits and appealing to a casual audience.

One of the game's most phenomenal features was its trading system. It allowed players to trade items, personalize their cars, and connect with others, creating an economy that was both exciting and rewarding. It felt like an organic way to earn and show off the hard work you’d put into the game. However, that system has now been abandoned in favor of a cash-grab Rocket Pass that’s entirely focused on squeezing every last penny out of its player base. Instead of encouraging community interaction, Rocket League now pushes players to spend real money on cosmetics, stripping away the sense of achievement that once came with building up a unique inventory.

The aggressive microtransactions, the shift to a free-to-play model, and the emphasis on item shops have all chipped away at the essence of what made Rocket League so engaging. What was once a tight-knit community of passionate players has now become overshadowed by an ever-changing landscape of cosmetics and battle passes.

Don’t get me wrong—the core mechanics are still there, and the potential for greatness hasn’t completely vanished. But it’s hard not to feel disheartened by how far Rocket League has strayed from its roots. As someone who’s invested years into this game, it’s disappointing to see the dev team lose sight of what made it a beloved title in the first place. I hope one day they rediscover the heart and passion that originally made Rocket League such a phenomenon. 

I first played Rocket League in the fall of 2015, and from that moment, it became a significant part of my gaming life. The countless hours spent mastering aerials, the thrill of intense matches, and the lasting friendships forged along the way are memories I’ll always cherish. However, it is with much pain and hesitation that I say this: until this game rediscovers the magic that made it so special, this Grand Champ is hanging up his car for possibly the last time.

One of the reasons why this game is so hard is because it is literally the only game of its kind and basically exists in its own genre. You can consider it a hybrid of racing/sports game, but any Rocket League player will tell you that neither of those genres will remotely prepare you for success here. If you've played some FPS games, you have transferrable skill for pretty much any FPS title that simplifies the learning curve, same thing goes for 3rd person Action RPG's, the list goes on. There is literally no uneven ground for new players starting out with Rocket League, because no other game like it has ever been made and no advantage you can have (no P2W at all, thank God). The mechanics are deceptively simple but ridiculously difficult to master, and the skill ceiling continues to rise after almost a decade. The insane thing is - unlike 99% of other live-service/online multiplayer titles, this game has not had a single significant or fundamental change to its core gameplay since the day of launch. No changes to online map design, car speed, boost speed/amount, literally nothing. The gameplay is so insanely hard yet so immensely satisfying, it has retained its community and fanbase over time on these merits alone, despite Epic Games basically tossing it to the side and ignoring it. Would love to see a tiny bit of effort made to server quality, bit more community interaction and variety of content, but other than that - Rocket League is one of the greatest online games ever made.

Rocket League on the surface is a great concept for a game.  In fact, it's got a lot of great features.  The greatest challenge for most games is 'Matchmaking'.  Video Game Devs / Pubs seem to value speed over accuracy.  So this means that when you play Rocket League for 6 years, and are ranked based on overall 'win / loss ratio' (regardless of your actual stats / execution).  This means you will play people who barely know how to kickoff, and people who are air dribbling and flip resetting in PLATINUM.  Plat is ideally your slightly above average player.  How hard would it be to stat track air dribblers vs air dribblers for matchmaking (Of course this is a simple example.)

Talking about Rocket League's matchmaking and performance overall is... well... very fast.  That's a good thing, no doubt.  But most serious players would rather wait double the amount of time, or even triple for some and play a team that's 'closer to their skill level / play style' than simply play someone with a similar MMR.  This is what takes a good game and makes it... well... miserable.  I often hear my team mates say things like "Here we go... we play super easy people, get a win, then play sky freaks two games back to back, division down, then play easy guys again."  It's a vicious circle and overcoming it requires one thing.  ALL TEAM MEMBERS, Spending hours a week in Training.  AKA, No Life.

Therefore, I can't recommend it.  Even though it's got so many great qualities, the overall experience for tons of people is a let down due to the reasons above.  If they ever rework the matchmaking, simply taking match data / play style data, and putting people together this way, most people will get stuck in the MMR Matchmaking nightmare.

It's a great game, a great idea. Leaving a review on steam is almost redundant seeing as it's a legacy title, but still, after... what, near enough 10 years, I still get packet loss in this game like no other, every session I'll go through a period of games where I, team mates, opposition, the ball, is at the very least wobbling every few seconds if not lag warping entirely. This does not happen in other games, but it always happens in Rocket League.

Most of the good bits of the game were there 10 years ago, since then they have experimented with monetization elements and different ways of doing cross franchise marketing. The only thing that's been added that's really good for your average, play every now and again player, in my opinion, was tournaments. They even removed player to player item trading, which sucks when you get 2 or 3 of something and would like to give one to a friend. Cosmetics of course don't really matter, there are different car hitboxes but the meta hit box is I believe accessible to all in a baseline car model, plus at the level the majority of players are at, it really doesn't matter (but yet is a thing). Yet I feel like 10 years ago I'd be more excited about getting a drop than I do these days opening a free loot box and inevitably getting something I already have, or worse something that's just... you know... another fairly normal looking set of wheels... forcibly painted lime green, wow, how lucky am I? The random chance to get items painted different colours (which you can't override) sounds cool on the surface, but ever so often you get a drop and think... well the default version I like, but I'm really not sure all of that bright pink is helping at all. I even got a new car model the other day, but it's forcibly painted sky blue, and you can't fully change the colour when customizing the car. Making me feel like I got a crappy knock of version of a car skin... yea, thanks. It's just niggling stuff like that which makes this game really irritating. 

Add in the hugely toxic player base, with constant chat rage, frequent unfriendliness, unkindness in games, play for any amount of time over a day and you'll get AFK team mates ESPECIALLY in tournaments. One goal goes in, 25% chance a team mate instant rage quits the match, ESPECIALLY in ranked where it actually matters. Yea... it's a great game but has great problems as well. 

tl;dr Rocket League, more like Rocket Lag, Epic games more like Epic Fail.

A Disappointing Stagnation:
One of the most glaring issues is the lack of innovation. Despite spending a considerable amount of time with the game, I’ve found myself facing the same playlist and features repeatedly. It’s disheartening to see that the game has not evolved or introduced new elements to keep the experience fresh. For a game that has been out for a while, this stagnation feels like a missed opportunity to engage and retain players.
On a positive note, the game’s visual appeal is noteworthy. The vibrant colors and detailed graphics add a lively touch to the matches. 
I’m left with a bittersweet taste. While the game still impresses with its vibrant colors and solid team-building mechanics, it falls short in several crucial areas that have dampened my enthusiasm.

Rocket League can feel like an exercise in sheer frustration, blending the worst elements of soccer and vehicular chaos into a disjointed mess that seems designed to push your patience to its absolute limit. The controls, while deceptively simple, often leave you flailing aimlessly, trying to land the perfect aerial shot only to miss entirely or send the ball in the wrong direction. Matches frequently devolve into chaotic car pile-ups, with little room for strategy or finesse, turning every game into a haphazard, luck-driven nightmare. The matchmaking can be brutally unforgiving, pitting you against players who seem to have mastered every trick while you struggle to even stay in control of your car. And let’s not forget the toxic community that often accompanies this kind of competitive online game, where one mistake can lead to a barrage of insults from teammates who care way too much about a game that feels more like a chore than fun. Instead of wasting time grinding through Rocket League, constantly replaying the same frustrating matches with little reward, you could be doing something more enjoyable and rewarding—reading, exercising, or playing a game that doesn’t make you question why you’re wasting hours of your life chasing a virtual ball with a car that can’t even turn properly.

Somehow, the crazy video game about flying cars playing football has made it into the pinnacle of e-sports gaming. The depth of the physics engine must have surprised the developers themselves; professional players have invented so many new mechanics since the game's launch that the way the game is played now is almost unrecognizable. Because of its high skill ceiling and the importance of team tactics, Rocket Leauge feels more rewarding the more time you put into the game. And it's definitely worth your time, especially if you team up with someone and take the game seriously.

Rocket League, oh Rocket League, how I've loved you for so long. The thrill of the aerial goals, the satisfaction of a well-timed save, the camaraderie of teaming up with friends... it’s all still there. But, and it’s a big but, since the acquisition, it's like the devs found a new turbo boost button labeled "$$$" and forgot about everything else.

Remember when updates used to bring exciting new features? Yeah, me neither. It’s been cash grab after cash grab, with the innovation meter stuck on empty. New cars? Pay up. New decals? Pay up. Want to blink? That'll cost you too. Meanwhile, meaningful updates and features are as scarce as a unicorn at a demolition derby.

Sure, the core gameplay remains the same – it's the game we all know and love. But with each passing day, the lack of growth makes it feel like an old car with a fresh coat of paint – shiny on the outside, but still the same under the hood.

If you're new, you'll have a blast. If you're a veteran, prepare for the slow, painful realization that this game has turned into a money pit. Rocket League is like that old friend who you love dearly but can't help but notice they've become a bit... materialistic.

Epic needs to give Psyonix back their game. Instead of using the new resources that Epic brings with their shitload of Fortnite money, they instead remove nearly every feature liked by the community. Trading, and crates both axed. It's sad to see how poorly Rocket League has been treated. I miss Jon Sandman Crate Wars and Blind Trading videos, he's now forced to play CS and has fallen off considerable, though absolutely no hate towards him absolute GOAT of my childhood. I've been playing since 2015 on PS4 and I've never been more disappointed in this game. There's not even an incentive to play competitive anymore, I was C2 for the longest time and now I'm barely hitting C1 and I've counted more than a Googol of GCs and throwers in my ranked games. I've thankfully not run into many smurfs but the smurfing problem in the lower ranks is abhorrent. I personally have a friend that has 6 RL accounts literally numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. I just can't enjoy this game anymore, all the fun of trading on the side, playing the market, and making cool as fuck cars was so fun. Now instead of a 5$ BM that's meh in quality it's now 20$ for any BM. Furthermore before they removed trading the item shop would absolutely break the market at times. I still remember when they released TW Octane, Fennec, Dominus, and Zombas and they absolutely crushed the prices at the time. In essence this game has lost one of its core identities in favor of corporate greed. I can't believe it has come to this, if you told me this is what the game would be like 8 years ago I would laugh in your face and call you schizo, but the only hallucination I'm having is believing this game is fun.

TL:DR: Epic has absolutely gutted the game and its horrible ranked system makes the game unbearable to try and work towards anything.

Look, I get the idea. At the time this caused a big stink in the mid-2010s, it was smack dab in the middle of another wave of absolute horse manure culture war outrage against video games. These devs were pUsHiNg tHe BoUnDaRiEs oF fReE sPeEcH... which I'm all for, don't get me wrong. But the game's ass. Its controls are trash. The AI's trash. There's little variety in what are supposed to be shockingly brutal execution animations, many of which are tame compared to the kind of ♥♥♥♥ Manhunt let you do in 2003. The "Antagonist" is the exact archetype that gets parodied by actual good games like GTA or Postal 2, but it takes itself completely seriously, and not even in a way that's so bad, it becomes funny. It's just boring and eye-roll inducing. It's a game that says absolutely nothing while pretending like it's got something to say. This game came out in 2015. By then, so many other games have allowed their players to be complete animals, and were exceptional for it. More games have released since 2015 that let you play as a complete animal, and were better games for letting you do so, and this game CLEARLY had no influence on ANY of that. It's... it's so... boring. This was supposed to make people feel outraged, right? The only outrage I'm experiencing is from having spent more than an hour giving this thing a chance. I'd rather go back to Hotline Miami. Genuinely. There's more gratuitous fun to be had there, with better controls, while having a style and personality, and a soundtrack that isn't just a constant moody droning. Yeah, sure, this game has the right to exist. Sex with Hitler and that Alex Jones game also have a right to exist. But Christ, man. There's better games out there that let you do worse things for the fun of it without pretending like it's doing anything bigger, and the ones that do use their violence for a point, they do it better than this could've ever dreamed. Treat yourself and get those instead.

It;s Rocket League. It's the best game ever made.

You know when you are playing and you just lose track of time? This game is one of those - A very addictive, difficult-to-master and competitive multiplayer game. 

It takes tremendous time to learn the mechanics of this game, and the better you are at the mechanics the more beautiful you play. It is that simple. Multiplayer matches are at the higher levels unforgiving and ruthless - you make one small mistake and you are punished for it. 

A match is (in general) five minutes, goes fast, it is easy and over before you know it. That makes it fun, you do not have to sink in around an hour (looking at you MOBAs) for a game, it is rewarding and it feels SO good when you succeed to jump of the wall with the ball, air control it while spinning it into the net. Wow. 

You put on your favorite playlist, enjoy a small amount of time to play games for a nice time... and that should be it for 20 minutes of fun. However, it is not sufficient. At all.

The addiction creeps up on you. Just one more game. Just one more training. Just one more wall dribble. You begin to play more and more. You become bitter for not being better, for not making that crazy shot, or for not having better teammates (because they are the reason you lose right?). The game can, if not careful, bring out a bad side of you. 

I've played with chat muted majority of the time. Got a lot of hours played as you can see. Having a muted chat does not stop random teammates from getting angry for whatever reason, losing the game on purpose, driving into you constantly or just messing with you because they have the power to. Multiplayer in this game is the best and the worst. 

I have stopped playing this game now. I do, however, recommend you to try it for the competitiveness, the adrenaline rush, the joy and that amazing rewarding feeling of doing crazy dribbles and using the mechanics to the fullest. I recommend that you try to have some fun with it, more than I have had.

However, be aware of your limits. Be aware of a community that is immature. Be aware that you can spend time on better things. Be aware that when you close the game and hours have passed you have not learned anything real. Why not learn a language, coding, or clean, or learn to be a better person with the time? Because that not as fun. Period.

With that said: To make that double tap-bounce of the wall-hitting into the net after HOURS of training... few things can feel more rewarding on an individual level. I dare you to not let it get its claws in you and bring out that competitive monster. Go try it, I dare you.
